title: EU aid vital to Western Balkan coal exit – utilities
subtitle: (Montel) Western Balkan state-owned utilities will find it difficult to ditch coal-fired generation and transition to green energy without substantial EU aid, the SET industry event in Trebinje, Bosnia and Herzegovina heard late on Wednesday.
body:
“If we are to reach decarbonisation targets, we need more support from the EU to carry out the transition of our coal regions,” said Luka Petrovic, the manager of Bosnian power utility Ers.
Coal currently accounts for 60-95% of power generation in the Western Balkans, depending on the country, and 60% of the region’s electricity exports.
As the state power provider, Ers must continue to operate two coal-fired plants, with a combined capacity of 600 MW, until sufficient replacement renewables capacity is online.
“Both facilities now operate well below their capacity and we have been facing dozens of unplanned outages due to outdated equipment and low-quality coal,” Petrovic told the event. “We cannot obtain loans from banks to revamp them or maintain them from our own operating funds.”
The same sentiment was voiced by Dusan Zivkovic, the general manager of Serbian state-owned utility Eps, who said that the inflexibility of financial institutions was hampering decarbonisation efforts in the region.
“No power utility in the Western Balkans will compromise its priorities – primarily energy security and social peace – for the sake of energy transition, [so] we need sustainable green transition financing mechanisms,” said Zivkovic.
CBAMHowever, the introduction of the EU’s carbon tax – the carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) – in 2026 may force the region’s utilities to decarbonise before the 2050 target date, Zivkovic and Petrovic said.
“The price of [power] after CBAM becomes the reality might become a turning point for the governments’ policies towards decarbonisation,” said Zivkovic.
